channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pakistani Leader Moves Quickly to Form Government
item.description: Former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif named the next finance minister even as votes from Saturday’s election were still being being tallied and outrage grew over accusations of vote-rigging.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Is Canada’s Oil Too Dirty for Europe?
item.description: As the American debate over the Keystone XL pipeline continues, Canadian politicians are waging a vigorous campaign to argue that oil from its tar sands shouldn’t be classified as dirtier than oil from other sources.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE
item.media:description: Opponents to the Keystone XL pipeline at a U.S. State Department public hearing in Grand Island, Nebraska, in April. The pipeline would pass through Nebraska.

item.title: Chinese Leaders Warn of ‘Dangerous’ Western Values
item.description: A reported Communist Party directive seemed to reflect determination to preserve top-down political control in the face of potential economic liberalizati0n.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Bulgarian Vote Fails to Produce Clear Winner
item.description: With turnout at a record-low 53 percent, no party won enough support to govern alone, and commentators say the real fight for power is only just beginning.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW BRUNWASSER

item.title: Letter from Europe: For Merkel, an Image to Be Managed
item.description: Angela Merkel, who remains immensely popular, has distanced herself from scandals besetting her coalition parties. And in a bid to capture new voters, she has shifted her party leftward.
item.dc:creator: By JUDY DEMPSEY

item.title: Britain’s Conservatives Split Over Europe
item.description: A clamor for Britain to exit the European Union appeared to be spreading within the dominant Conservative Party on Monday ahead of Prime Minister David Cameron’s visit to Washington.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: India Ink: India’s Middle Class: Growth Engine or Loose Wheel?
item.description: Structural and cultural weaknesses mean India’s future economic growth rests on a shaky foundation.
item.dc:creator: By SAMBUDDHA MITRA MUSTAFI
item.media:description: A demonstration outside the Presidential Palace in New Delhi against the gang rape of a 23-year-old woman in the capital on Dec. 16, 2012.

item.title: India Ink: Should Manmohan Singh Resign?
item.description: As corruption allegations again engulf the scandal-tainted Congress Party, calls for India’s prime minister to step down are increasing.
item.dc:creator: By HEATHER TIMMONS
item.media:description: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh at a press conference in Berlin, Germany, on Apr. 11.

item.title: North Korea Names Armed Forces Minister
item.description: The appointment is seen as part of Kim Jong-un’s effort to tighten his grip on power.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: South Korean Leader Apologizes for Aide’s Behavior
item.description: Accusations against President Park Geun-hye’s main spokesman, the latest allegation of wrongdoing against a member of her staff, have upset South Koreans who see sexual harassment as a widespread problem.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: After Fair Trade Coffee, Fair Trade Shea
item.description: Some of the West African women who harvest shea are coming to New York this week to talk to the multinationals that buy their product about how to make sure everyone benefits.
item.dc:creator: By FRANKIE EDOZIEN
item.media:description: Women from a cooperative in Burkino Faso prepare shea butter.)

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: May 13
item.description: Turmoil after the Pakistan election; countries lobby in Washington’s immigration debate; Chinese automakers put down roots in Detroit; renewed appreciation for Buckminster Fuller; Nadal and Williams triumph in Madrid.
item.dc:creator: By INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: A poster for former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif in a cafe in Lahore, Pakistan. The country’s election officials said final results would take days.

item.title: San Diego Mayor Building Economic Bridges to Tijuana
item.description: Mayor Bob Filner sees the border as a potential economic engine for the region, a remarkable shift in a city once viewed as a hotbed for illegal immigration.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER MEDINA
item.media:description: Three-hour waits are not unusual at the San Diego border.

item.title: Chinese Automakers Quietly Build a Detroit Presence
item.description: Dozens of companies from China are quietly planting roots in Detroit, investing in American businesses and new vehicle technology in what is seen as a first step toward the sale of Chinese cars in the United States.
item.dc:creator: By BILL VLASIC
item.media:credit: Fabrizio Costantini for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hong Su, center, heads a research center in Plymouth, Mich., set up by Changan, a Chinese automaker. Changan hired about 20 Detroit engineers, some laid off from Detroit auto companies.

item.title: Turkish Officials Appeal for Calm in Wake of Twin Bombings
item.description: The authorities said they had arrested nine people in the bombings in a border town near Syria, as the government moved to keep the attacks from inflaming tensions.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Relatives mourned two people killed Saturday in Reyhanli, Turkey, on the Syrian border. Officials have appealed for calm.

item.title: Few Vote in Bulgaria as Apathy Prevails
item.description: Despite earlier protests forcing the government to resign, the election has aroused little interest or discussion. Still, accusations of corruption have popped up.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW BRUNWASSER
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Boiko Borisov, center, greeted supporters as he left a polling station in Sofia, Bulgaria, on Sunday.

item.title: Nawaz Sharif Starts Talks on Forming Government in Pakistan
item.description: Former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif was projected to be the big winner in Saturday’s election, which was marred by violence and reports of fraud at the polls.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: A poster for former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif in a cafe in Lahore, Pakistan. The country’s election officials said final results would take days.

item.title: Cyberattacks on Rise Against U.S. Corporations
item.description: Officials said the aim in a new wave of attacks was not espionage but sabotage, and that the source seemed to be in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and NICOLE PERLROTH

item.title: Pickering Defends Benghazi Panel’s Inquiry
item.description: Thomas R. Pickering, who led the State Department’s inquiry into the attack on a diplomatic outpost, said there had been no need to interview the secretary of state.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Thomas R. Pickering in an interview on CBS on Sunday.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Lao She’s Art Collection Auctioned Amid Enthusiasm
item.description: A collection of paintings belonging to the writer Lao She, who killed himself in the Cultural Revolution, and his wife, the painter Hu Jieqing, were auctioned in Beijing amid considerable excitement.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A screenshot from the Web site of Cultural China, www.cultural-china.com, showing the writer Lao She.

item.title: Homophobia Linked to Murder in Russia
item.description: Three men were arrested in connection with the death of a 23-year-old man in Volgograd, and the findings were a rare acknowledgment during a period of rising antigay sentiment from officials.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: South Korea Seeks Journalist’s Arrest in Defamation Case
item.description: Prosecutors said Choo Chin-woo had “spread false information” through articles and a podcast linking President Park Geun-hye’s brother to a relative’s killing.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Afghans Say an American Tortured Civilians
item.description: An arrest warrant has been issued for a man that Afghan officials say is an American and part of a Special Forces unit operating in Wardak Province.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Greek Tax Crackdown Yields Little Revenue
item.description: Tax evasion lies at the heart of the Greek financial collapse, yet efforts to collect billions of euros in taxes from deadbeat residents have yielded little additional revenue.
item.dc:creator: By LANDON THOMAS Jr. and ELENI VARVITSIOTI

item.title: 2 Candidates in Iran Draw Strong Reactions
item.description: After Esfandiar Rahim Mashaei and former President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani registered for the June election, the country’s governing establishment responded with anger.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
